issue.title: Take stock of all algorithms
issue.body:
This issue to capture what we discussed today (also for the benefit of @christianpaquin): 

- Create a current view as to where we stand for each algorithm (round3 readiness, code level, etc.)
- Decide whether/how to parcel out work to arrive at 0.5 release readiness (incl. whether/how to address common code issues as per #849).
- Probably also list release-criteria for 0.5 (not discussed today but in a previous meeting).

@dstebila @xvzcf are working on this.

comment.body: That seems fine to me, @xvzcf.

issue.title: (Re-)define CI process flow
issue.body:
This issue is to discuss, formulate and agree, initially the need for and eventually the CI strategy going forward (and then implement it).

As already discussed, there are different types of (CI) tests:
- quick sanity checks (such as styletest)
- baseline build tests (with different build-options)
- quick cross platform tests
- deeper tests validating all algorithms are operating OK
- long-running tests like address-sanitizer or timecop

Based on this a strawman proposal:
- Classify all tests we have into one of these categories: must pass 1) during PR, 2) for audit, 3) for main merge, 4) for release
- Build out the pipeline accordingly, maybe using github actions using dedicated compute resources for 2+4 
- Tests passing for 3 should also trigger downstream integration tests
- 1,2,3 would be prerequisite for 4 but 4 could mandate additional tests (we may not even have yet).
- 1 should have a (normal average) time-to-completion target time of 15 minutes; 2 can be arbitrary long if it's gating nothing but 4; 3 should deliver pass/fail within 1 hour. 
- Tests for 2 surely would not have to run cross-platform (though it might be nice)

Rationale: We should be able to make progress resolving issues (at their respective level of complexity: Simple ones should be CI'd&closed fast; downstream problems detected within reasonable time (but automatically); "deep" algorithm problems should be unearthed and resolved in a separate time frame).

Alternative proposals welcome. Proposals for classifying the tests as well as how to implement them, too.

@dstebila @xvzcf @jschanck @christianpaquin (any one else not party to the conversation up to now as well, of course) please click "+1" if you agree we should tackle this problem and if you have more time, additional feedback/suggestions would be great.

comment.body: Given that RedHat terminated CentOS development in December 2020, I'm not inclined to continue with CentOS support unless we hear a clear demand for it.

issue.title: Crashing on Android after trying to create new Signature
issue.body:
Hello! I'm using liboqs-java on Android. I have compiled liboqs.so and libjni.so for Android x86_64 successfully and the modules are loaded successfully by Android. I copied the CMakeLists.txt made by [Hatzen](https://github.com/Hatzen/LibOQSTestApp/tree/master/app/src/main/c). 

However, after my main activity loads, I try to call the example code from examples/SigExamples.java the app crashes on this line:

`Signature signer = new Signature("DEFAULT");`

Here's the logcat from Android [(click here to see full crash log)](https://gist.github.com/taimoorgit/8b51c84c614d35f309d4f0e22a7ec9e8):

```
2021-01-28 11:14:44.807 2263-2263/io.trustwave.polarisclientapp A/olarisclientap: java_vm_ext.cc:577] JNI DETECTED ERROR IN APPLICATION: use of invalid jobject 0x7efd45de09d0
    java_vm_ext.cc:577]     from org.openquantumsafe.Signature$SignatureDetails org.openquantumsafe.Signature.get_sig_details()
2021-01-28 11:14:44.946 2263-2263/io.trustwave.polarisclientapp A/olarisclientap: runtime.cc:655] Runtime aborting...
```

Is this an issue with Android, the way I compiled liboqs, the Android version or an issue with the liboqs-java wrapper?

Thanks - Taimoor

comment.body: Closing in favour of #11.

issue.title: OpenSSL linking configuration mismatch between oqs (C) and oqs-sys
issue.body:
In the primary C library, linking to OpenSSL [is disabled on Windows](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/blob/fb5484cda68dac115dc563593c68388f89444b95/.CMake/alg_support.cmake#L13). However, in this crate, it is [enabled by default on all platforms](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs-rust/blob/main/oqs-sys/build.rs#L44). Without `--no-default-features`, this causes a number of compilation errors on Windows when trying to build `oqs` in the build script.

Please consider not linking to OpenSSL by default, especially on Windows, although it causes installation headaches on all platforms.

comment.body: I checked out the branch and confirmed it fixes the linking issue. My tests also run after configuring the stack size.

issue.title: OpenSSL linking configuration mismatch between oqs (C) and oqs-sys
issue.body:
In the primary C library, linking to OpenSSL [is disabled on Windows](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/blob/fb5484cda68dac115dc563593c68388f89444b95/.CMake/alg_support.cmake#L13). However, in this crate, it is [enabled by default on all platforms](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs-rust/blob/main/oqs-sys/build.rs#L44). Without `--no-default-features`, this causes a number of compilation errors on Windows when trying to build `oqs` in the build script.

Please consider not linking to OpenSSL by default, especially on Windows, although it causes installation headaches on all platforms.

comment.body:
This is very unrelated, but it would be cool if we could get this `liboqs-rust` to work with the `openssl-sys` crate. To get this compiling, the `build.rs` logic has duplicated some of the searching and link logic of that crate. It also has a vendored feature to get around the headaches of needing OpenSSL present on your system.

Its probably not possible, at least not easily, since liboqs links to it, but it would be a great feature. I tried tinkering with it but the linker on both Linux and Windows isn't happy with the idea.

issue.title: (Re-)define CI process flow
issue.body:
This issue is to discuss, formulate and agree, initially the need for and eventually the CI strategy going forward (and then implement it).

As already discussed, there are different types of (CI) tests:
- quick sanity checks (such as styletest)
- baseline build tests (with different build-options)
- quick cross platform tests
- deeper tests validating all algorithms are operating OK
- long-running tests like address-sanitizer or timecop

Based on this a strawman proposal:
- Classify all tests we have into one of these categories: must pass 1) during PR, 2) for audit, 3) for main merge, 4) for release
- Build out the pipeline accordingly, maybe using github actions using dedicated compute resources for 2+4 
- Tests passing for 3 should also trigger downstream integration tests
- 1,2,3 would be prerequisite for 4 but 4 could mandate additional tests (we may not even have yet).
- 1 should have a (normal average) time-to-completion target time of 15 minutes; 2 can be arbitrary long if it's gating nothing but 4; 3 should deliver pass/fail within 1 hour. 
- Tests for 2 surely would not have to run cross-platform (though it might be nice)

Rationale: We should be able to make progress resolving issues (at their respective level of complexity: Simple ones should be CI'd&closed fast; downstream problems detected within reasonable time (but automatically); "deep" algorithm problems should be unearthed and resolved in a separate time frame).

Alternative proposals welcome. Proposals for classifying the tests as well as how to implement them, too.

@dstebila @xvzcf @jschanck @christianpaquin (any one else not party to the conversation up to now as well, of course) please click "+1" if you agree we should tackle this problem and if you have more time, additional feedback/suggestions would be great.

comment.body:
> What I meant was scheduling a nightly job if and only if a new_commit API trigger was made.

As I have no idea how to do that I went hunting for information. Two ideas now:
1) Create a CCI artifact to store the information that (which) tasks need to be run during the night. Didn't find a way yet how to programatically retrieve "the latest" artifact, though: Only found [this information how to get a specific build's artifacts](https://circleci.com/docs/2.0/artifacts/#downloading-all-artifacts-for-a-build-on-circleci). But the cronjob can't know the number of the "latest build", so I don't see a way forward here.
2) Alternatively, store the same "run-later" information, say via wget, on a server of our choice and trigger nightly CCI tasks from there (via curl task-trigger): That should be doable pretty much straight away.

Other ideas?

> Given that RedHat terminated CentOS development in December 2020, I'm not inclined to continue with CentOS support unless we hear a clear demand for it.

Good point that made me also streamline `open-quantum-safe/ci-containers`: Can you and/or @xvzcf please take a look? Optimizing workflow a bit, I didn't do a PR but placed this in a new branch `main`: If OK, please set that as the new default branch along the lines of #795 so we can dump `master`: Thanks in advance.

issue.title: Cannot run tests?
issue.body:
MacOS 10.15.7, Xcode-12.4 (probably not relevant here, but...).

Initially, I could not run tests because the make-script could not load dynamic library. *Problem with the upstream, unresolved.*

Changing the build to producing static library, the tests can run - but some are skipped with this message:
```
test_tlsextms needs the dynamic engine feature enabled
```

What's this "dynamic engine feature"? How do I enable it - just by removing `no-shared` from the `./Configuration ...` command?

And why the README tells to build this fork with `no-shared`? Is this restriction still valid?

comment.body:
OK - so the script above does proper shared oqs-openssl testing on OSX?! Cool.

So may I invite you to contribute via PR this code to fix https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssl/blob/9e342427ead2945c7a757e8497d3d1cb7ae6d578/.circleci/config.yml#L81-L85

?

issue.title: OpenSSL linking configuration mismatch between oqs (C) and oqs-sys
issue.body:
In the primary C library, linking to OpenSSL [is disabled on Windows](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/blob/fb5484cda68dac115dc563593c68388f89444b95/.CMake/alg_support.cmake#L13). However, in this crate, it is [enabled by default on all platforms](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs-rust/blob/main/oqs-sys/build.rs#L44). Without `--no-default-features`, this causes a number of compilation errors on Windows when trying to build `oqs` in the build script.

Please consider not linking to OpenSSL by default, especially on Windows, although it causes installation headaches on all platforms.

comment.body: The main problem is the `openssl-sys` crate `build.rs` does not expose the location where it found OpenSSL. Otherwise I could pass it on to `liboqs`I did look into this.

issue.title: Manually-specified variables were not used by the project
issue.body:
When building on Windows, this error occurs and the build fails:
```
Chef@WJ68NAB4 ~\App\shared
$ cargo build
    Blocking waiting for file lock on package cache
    Updating git repository `https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs-rust`
    Updating crates.io index
    Blocking waiting for file lock on package cache
    Blocking waiting for file lock on package cache
    Blocking waiting for file lock on build directory
   Compiling regex-syntax v0.6.22
   Compiling regex v1.4.3
   Compiling env_logger v0.8.3
   Compiling bindgen v0.57.0
   Compiling oqs-sys v0.5.0 (https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs-rust?branch=main#67abcfcb)
error: failed to run custom build command for `oqs-sys v0.5.0 (https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs-rust?branch=main#67abcfcb)`

Caused by:
  process didn't exit successfully: `C:\Users\Chef\App\shared\target\debug\build\oqs-sys-318ffd7313b93664\build-script-build` (exit code: 101)
  --- stderr
  CMake Warning:
    Manually-specified variables were not used by the project:

      CMAKE_BUILD_TYPE
      CMAKE_CXX_FLAGS
      CMAKE_CXX_FLAGS_RELEASE


  thread 'main' panicked at '
  command did not execute successfully, got: exit code: 1

  build script failed, must exit now', C:\Users\Chef\.cargo\registry\src\github.com-1ecc6299db9ec823\cmake-0.1.45\src\lib.rs:894:5
  note: run with `RUST_BACKTRACE=1` environment variable to display a backtrace
```

Versions:
- Rust 1.51.0-nightly (d1aed50ab 2021-01-26)
- cmake 3.19.4

comment.body: I don't think this is a problem of this crate and just a symptom of the problems solved by #30

issue.title: OpenSSL linking configuration mismatch between oqs (C) and oqs-sys
issue.body:
In the primary C library, linking to OpenSSL [is disabled on Windows](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/blob/fb5484cda68dac115dc563593c68388f89444b95/.CMake/alg_support.cmake#L13). However, in this crate, it is [enabled by default on all platforms](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs-rust/blob/main/oqs-sys/build.rs#L44). Without `--no-default-features`, this causes a number of compilation errors on Windows when trying to build `oqs` in the build script.

Please consider not linking to OpenSSL by default, especially on Windows, although it causes installation headaches on all platforms.

comment.body: Ah, that sucks :/ Good to know though.

issue.title: Missing AVX2 version of Classic McEliece
issue.body: We only pull in the vec (vectorized plain C) implementation of Classic McEliece from PQClean; we should also pull in the avx2 implementation.

issue.title: Missing AVX2 version of Classic McEliece
issue.body: We only pull in the vec (vectorized plain C) implementation of Classic McEliece from PQClean; we should also pull in the avx2 implementation.

issue.title: Use valgrind to check for secret-dependent branching on 'audit' branches
issue.body: This PR should run the full set of constant-time checks on #881.

comment.body: Thanks John! To make sure I understand: The "issues" files log places that don't pass Valgrind's checks.  For each of these we've checked with the authors that they believe these are not problematic from a security perspective.  But an ideal version would have no issues files.

issue.title: Use valgrind to check for secret-dependent branching on 'audit' branches
issue.body: This PR should run the full set of constant-time checks on #881.

comment.body:
> Thanks John! To make sure I understand: The "issues" files log places that don't pass Valgrind's checks. For each of these we've checked with the authors that they believe these are not problematic from a security perspective. But an ideal version would have no issues files.

Almost. The "issues" files log errors that are either awaiting review or are known to be actual problems. Once we have review of an "issue" it should be moved to "passes".

Here's the current status.

The open issues for SIDH/SIKE are:
* sidh_vartime_bingcd_final_C24 
* sike_vartime_bingcd_final_C24
* sike_compressed_verify_ladder
* sike_memcmp

The first two can be moved to "passes" based on reviews from #888. The second two will be fixed by #914. I'll resolve all four issues once #914 merges.

Bike and HQC have genuine non-constant time behaviour, documented by:
* bike_has_no_timing_protections
* hqc_fast_convolution_mult
* hqc_gf_mul
* hqc_vect_set_random_fixed_weight

And there's one falcon issue that can be fixed by pulling from pqclean.
* falcon_hash_to_point_vartime

issue.title: Use valgrind to check for secret-dependent branching on 'audit' branches

issue.title: Support OpenSSL on Windows
issue.body:
Attempts to add support for OpenSSL on Windows. We probably should add this to the CI matrix as well.

See also https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs-rust/issues/17

comment.body: This is my first time dealing with testapproval.  Should we run the tests being held?  Who would trigger that?  Or can we decide it is not necessary for this PR (since the remaining tests are arm tests, unaffected by this PR) and just merge as is?

issue.title: Cannot run tests?
issue.body:
MacOS 10.15.7, Xcode-12.4 (probably not relevant here, but...).

Initially, I could not run tests because the make-script could not load dynamic library. *Problem with the upstream, unresolved.*

Changing the build to producing static library, the tests can run - but some are skipped with this message:
```
test_tlsextms needs the dynamic engine feature enabled
```

What's this "dynamic engine feature"? How do I enable it - just by removing `no-shared` from the `./Configuration ...` command?

And why the README tells to build this fork with `no-shared`? Is this restriction still valid?

comment.body:
> may I invite you to contribute via PR this code to fix

Sorry, it looks like I can't fork this repo, because I already forked the "main" OpenSSL.

It looks like my fix is comprised of these three parts (assuming LIBOQS and OQS-OPENSSL source trees have been cloned already):
1. Build and install LIBOQS_SHARED
2. Symlink the slared library `liboqs.0.dylib` to where OQS-OPENSSL will be installed
3. When configuring OQS-OPENSSL (shared), make sure the appropriate LDFLAGS are provided
     - that includes the correct RPATH settings

This allows "smooth" `make all` *and* `make test`. 

Can I also suggest that you change Xcode-11.9 to Xcode-12.4 or whatever's the closest to 12.4?

In the `config.yml` I did not see where the arguments to `./config` or `./Configure` are provided. `LDFLAGS` should become a part of those, IMHO.
